title: A survey of Zarankiewicz problem in geometry
abstract:
Abstract
One of the central topics in extremal graph theory is the study of the function e‚Äãx‚Äã(n,H)ùëíùë•ùëõùêªex(n,H), which represents the maximum number of edges a graph with nùëõn vertices can have while avoiding a fixed graph HùêªH as a subgraph. Tur√°n provided a complete characterization for the case when HùêªH is a complete graph on rùëür vertices. Erd≈ës, Stone, and Simonovits extended Tur√°n‚Äôs result to arbitrary graphs HùêªH with œá‚Äã(H)>2ùúíùêª2\chi(H)>2 (chromatic number greater than 2). However, determining the asymptotics of e‚Äãx‚Äã(n,H)ùëíùë•ùëõùêªex(n,H) for bipartite graphs HùêªH remains a widely open problem. A classical example of this is Zarankiewicz‚Äôs problem, which asks for the asymptotics of e‚Äãx‚Äã(n,Kt,t)ùëíùë•ùëõsubscriptùêæùë°ùë°ex(n,K_{t,t}).
In this paper, we survey Zarankiewicz‚Äôs problem, with a focus on graphs that arise from geometry. Incidence geometry, in particular, can be viewed as a manifestation of Zarankiewicz‚Äôs problem in geometrically defined graphs.
